tagged_story_for_tts:

"Ancient English roots.<[silence:1000]>Germanic words, Viking twists."
<[silence:2400]>
"Old English" refers to the language spoken in England from roughly 450–1150 AD—before the Normans arrived.<[silence:1200]> It’s the tongue of Beowulf, where "house" was hūs and "water" was wæter.<[silence:2400]>

Most words came from Germanic tribes (Angles, Saxons, Jutes), but Viking raids (8th–11th centuries) added Norse words like sky, egg, and they.<[silence:1200]> Grammar was complex: nouns had four cases (like German today), and verbs changed endings by person.<[silence:2400]>
Example: "Ic lufie þē" ("I love you") vs. "Hē lufaþ hīe" ("He loves her").<[silence:1200]>
The 1066 Norman Conquest buried Old English under French influence, but 10,000+ words survived—earth, apple, love.<[silence:2400]>
Three related subjects are runes and writing, language evolution, and medieval manuscripts.<[silence:1200]>
clean_story:
"Ancient English roots. Germanic words, Viking twists. "

"Old English" refers to the language spoken in England from roughly 450–1150 AD—before the Normans arrived. It’s the tongue of Beowulf, where "house" was hūs and "water" was wæter.

Most words came from Germanic tribes (Angles, Saxons, Jutes), but Viking raids (8th–11th centuries) added Norse words like sky, egg, and they. Grammar was complex: nouns had four cases (like German today), and verbs changed endings by person.
Example: "Ic lufie þē" ("I love you") vs. "Hē lufaþ hīe" ("He loves her").
The 1066 Norman Conquest buried Old English under French influence, but 10,000+ words survived—earth, apple, love.
Three related subjects are runes and writing, language evolution, and medieval manuscripts.
